description:
Candidatus Cyrtobacter comes is a recently discovered, uncultured bacterial species that belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria. It was first identified through metagenomic analysis of microbial communities found in the gut of the marine isopod Cyathura carinata.

The name "Candidatus Cyrtobacter comes" reflects its association with the host organism (Cyathura carinata) and its curved, rod-shaped cellular morphology. As a candidate species, it has not yet been formally described or isolated in pure culture, and its physiological and metabolic characteristics are largely inferred from genomic data.

Genome analysis suggests that Candidatus Cyrtobacter comes is a chemoorganotrophic bacterium, meaning it likely obtains energy and carbon from the oxidation of organic compounds. It appears to have a relatively small genome, indicative of a symbiotic or commensal lifestyle within the gut of its isopod host.

The precise role and interactions of Candidatus Cyrtobacter comes within the gut microbiome of Cyathura carinata are still under investigation. Further research is needed to elucidate its ecological significance, metabolic capabilities, and potential interactions with the host organism.
